<html><body><div><div class="article-body | article w-100"><p class="text | article-text">CAMBRIDGE, Illinois (KWQC) - The man charged with murder in the death of Trudy Appleby wants his trial moved.</p><p class="text | article-text">Public defenders filed a motion Tuesday seeking a change of venue.</p><p class="text | article-text">Jamison Fisher was <a href="https://www.kwqc.com/2025/08/14/man-indicted-appleby-disappearance/" target="_self" rel="" title="https://www.kwqc.com/2025/08/14/man-indicted-appleby-disappearance/">charged in August</a>, an arrest nearly three decades after Appleby disappeared. </p><p class="text | article-text">Police say he killed the 11-year-old in 1996 because her father <a href="https://www.kwqc.com/2025/11/20/prosecutors-trudy-appleby-killed-colona-over-drug-debt/" target="_self" rel="" title="https://www.kwqc.com/2025/11/20/prosecutors-trudy-appleby-killed-colona-over-drug-debt/">owed him a drug debt</a>.</p><p class="w-100"></p><p class="text | article-text">The case haunted the Quad-Cities for nearly three decades. Vigils were held every anniversary. Billboards posted over the years asked for new tips. Police never stopped searching. </p><p class="text | article-text">Media covered the case extensively, and <a href="https://www.kwqc.com/2025/11/20/girl-behind-picture-who-was-trudy-appleby/" target="_self" rel="" title="https://www.kwqc.com/2025/11/20/girl-behind-picture-who-was-trudy-appleby/">Appleby’s face</a> became one of the most recognizable in the Quad-Cities.</p><p class="text | article-text">According to Fisher’s lawyers, there have been at least 183 local television and newspaper stories since her disappearance. </p><p class="text | article-text">KWQC has continued to report on the case, including an <a href="https://www.kwqc.com/video/2025/11/21/jamison-fisher-interview-man-accused-killing-trudy-appleby-claims-innocence-jailhouse-interview/" target="_self" rel="" title="https://www.kwqc.com/video/2025/11/21/jamison-fisher-interview-man-accused-killing-trudy-appleby-claims-innocence-jailhouse-interview/">exclusive jailhouse interview</a> with Fisher in November, during which he maintained his innocence.</p><p class="w-100"></p><p class="text | article-text">Fisher’s lawyers say that’s enough to warrant a trial outside the Quad-Cities area.</p><p class="text | article-text">They’ve asked for the trial to be moved to McLean, Winnebago or Champaign counties.</p><p class="text | article-text">Meanwhile, motions filed Friday <a href="https://www.kwqc.com/2026/01/30/prosecutors-name-new-witnesses-29-year-old-appleby-murder-case/" target="_self" rel="" title="https://www.kwqc.com/2026/01/30/prosecutors-name-new-witnesses-29-year-old-appleby-murder-case/">named potential witnesses </a>for the prosecution. They include people associated with Fisher through drugs and former girlfriends who will testify that Fisher admitted his involvement in Appleby’s death.</p><p class="text | article-text">One witness will testify to seeing Fisher; a man who has since died; and another man “passing” her around for “sexual gratification” near a bridge in Colona the day she disappeared. Another witness will testify that after the arrest, he asked Fisher’s girlfriend to find out if he should move the “buried treasure.”</p><p class="w-100"></p><p class="text | article-text">KWQC is not naming the witnesses because none have been charged with crimes in connection with Appleby’s death.</p><p class="text | article-text">Though Appleby was last spotted in Moline, the case was filed in Henry County because it is the location where prosecutors say she was killed.</p><p class="text | article-text">Her remains have never been found.</p><p class="text | article-text">Fisher is next due in court on Feb. 27. </p><p class="copyright |"><i>Copyright 2026 KWQC. All rights reserved.</i></p></div></div></body></html>
